title: 103_hr3545
content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1993" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, and applies to members of Congress. SEC. 3. APPLICATION TO MEMBERS OF CONGRESS. Amends Section 591(b) of title 28, United States Code to include Senators, Representatives, Delegates, and Resident Commissioners within the scope of the Act. Section 591 of title 28, United States Code is amended to require specific information from a credible source for determining the need for a preliminary investigation within 15 days of receiving the information. The Attorney General must decide within 15 days whether there is enough evidence of a violation of Federal criminal law. If there is insufficient evidence, the matter is closed. If there is enough evidence, a preliminary investigation begins. If the determination cannot be made within 15 days, a preliminary investigation starts at the end of that period. 28, United States Code, amended to require specific information from a credible source for investigations. SEC. 5 amends Section 592(a)(2) of title 28, US Code to allow issuing subpoenas duces tecum. SEC. 6 addresses prosecutorial jurisdiction of independent counsel. SEC. 6 amends prosecutorial jurisdiction for independent counsel to focus on criminal law violations requested by the Attorney General. Amends prosecutorial jurisdiction for independent counsel to investigate and prosecute criminal law violations requested by the Attorney General, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. SEC. 7. Use of state and local prosecutors; staff of independent counsel. The amendment allows for the appointment of independent counsel prosecutors from State or local governments, with limitations on the number of compensated employees. The independent counsel can compensate employees at rates not exceeding GS-15 of the General Schedule. They should prioritize using Department of Justice personnel and consider appointing prosecutors from State or local governments. Each independent counsel is considered the head of a Federal agency for this purpose. SEC. 8 amends Section 593(f)(1) of title 28, United States Code regarding attorneys' fees. The court shall award fees if an individual is acquitted of all charges, no conviction is obtained, or if a conviction is overturned on appeal. The fees cover investigation, trial, and appeal. SEC. 9 addresses the treatment of classified information. SEC. 9 amends procedures for independent counsels accessing classified information, requiring adherence to government protocols. Failure to comply may result in removal. SEC. 10 amends compensation for independent counsels, setting per diem rate equal to level IV of Executive Schedule. Travel and lodging expenses in Washington are not covered after 1 year of service. SEC. 11 outlines authorities and duties of independent counsels. The amendment provides administrative support and office space for independent counsels, ensuring compliance with Department of Justice policies. The amendment expands the scope of enforcement of criminal laws and the release of information relating to criminal proceedings. It also imposes a limitation on expenditures for independent counsel offices after a 2-year period unless specifically authorized by an appropriations Act. SEC. 12. PERIODIC REPORTS. Section 595(a)(2) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to require independent counsels to annually report on their activities, including progress of investigations or prosecutions. The report must justify expenditures and provide general information on the work of the independent counsel. SEC. 13. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Section 596(a)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow for the removal of an independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies. Section 596(b)(2) is amended to give the court the authority to terminate an independent counsel's office under certain conditions. The petition can be made more than 2 years after the appointment of the independent counsel, based on the completion of the investigation or if it's not in the public interest. Section 596 of title 28, United States Code, allows for periodic reappointment of the independent counsel if the office has not terminated within 2 years of the original appointment. The court can reappoint the independent counsel every 2 years if the office is not terminated, following a review process to determine the appropriate person for the role. If the court fails to take action within 90 days after the 2-year period, the office of the independent counsel will terminate. SEC. 14. JOB PROTECTIONS FOR INDIVIDUALS UNDER INVESTIGATION. Sec. 597 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include job protection for individuals under investigation by the Department of Justice. It is prohibited for a government employee with authority over personnel actions to take adverse actions against individuals under investigation. The amendment to Sec. 597 of title 28, US Code provides job protection for individuals under investigation by the Department of Justice. It prohibits government employees from taking adverse personnel actions against individuals under investigation, unless the individual is convicted of a criminal offense. An individual under investigation by the Department of Justice can seek corrective action from the Merit Systems Protection Board. The amendment provides job protection and prohibits adverse personnel actions unless the individual is convicted of a criminal offense. SEC. 15. Amendment to Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, allows for job protection for individuals under investigation by the Department of Justice. SEC. 16. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit a report to Congress within one year of this Act's enactment, with recommendations to improve controls on costs of independent counsel offices.
